entries.title: House voting on rule to pave the way to final debate on Trump's tax-and-spending bill - US politics live
entries.snippet: The U.S. House of Representatives held a crucial procedural vote on Donald Trump's expansive $3.5 trillion tax-and-spending bill, paving the way for final debate. Despite intense lobbying from Speaker Mike Johnson and Trump, the vote's outcome remained uncertain due to slim Republican margins and internal dissent. Fiscal conservatives, particularly from the House Freedom Caucus, opposed the bill's deficit-increasing components, while moderates decried cuts to Medicaid and other safety net programs. Trump maintained the bill would spur unprecedented economic growth and denied it included Medicaid cuts, contradicting independent analyses. The bill, which narrowly passed the Senate, faces fierce opposition from Democrats who argue it benefits the wealthy at the expense of the middle class and vulnerable populations. Amid the legislative standoff, Trump also attacked critics on social media and threatened CNN over its reporting. Other highlights included a federal judge blocking Trump's asylum ban, the Pentagon halting some Ukraine aid, and controversy over “Alligator Alcatraz,” a harsh migrant detention facility in Florida. Democrats and even former President Obama criticized the bill, urging lawmakers to reject it. Delays due to weather and internal disagreements continued to hinder progress toward Trump’s targeted Independence Day passage.

entries.title: With public ban on band Bob Vylan, Trump appears to ease visa privacy rules to make a point
entries.snippet: The Trump administration has publicly revoked the U.S. visas of British punk-rap duo Bob Vylan following a controversial chant led by the band’s frontman at the Glastonbury Festival, where he encouraged the crowd to shout "Death to the IDF" in protest of the war in Gaza. Typically, visa decisions are confidential, but Deputy Secretary of State Christopher Landau announced the revocations on social media, citing the band's "hateful tirade." The band denied allegations of antisemitism, claiming they are being targeted for expressing political views. This case is part of a broader Trump administration campaign to revoke visas from individuals it believes advocate antisemitic or pro-militant messages. Secretary of State Marco Rubio recently stated that around 300 visas had been rescinded on similar grounds. This shift reflects a relaxed adherence to traditional privacy rules for visa decisions, aiming to highlight ideological standards for foreign visitors. Historical precedents of politically motivated visa revocations include figures like Charlie Chaplin and John Lennon. Amnesty International has criticized such ideological exclusions, viewing them as tools to suppress dissenting voices.

entries.title: Trump called this visa 'very bad' for Americans. Truth Social applied for one
entries.snippet: Truth Social, the social media company founded by former President Donald Trump, applied for an H-1B visa in June 2022 to employ a worker with a salary of $65,000, although it ultimately did not hire the employee. This application comes despite Trump’s frequent criticism of the H-1B visa program, suggesting it disadvantageous for U.S. workers and promoting an agenda to restrict such visas. Trump’s investment firm, led by his son-in-law Jared Kushner, had also been approved for hiring a foreign worker under the same visa program. This conflict highlights a discrepancy between Trump’s political stance on protecting American jobs and his businesses utilizing such immigration tools. Trump Media & Technology Group claimed the application was made under prior management and it terminated the process in November 2022. The H-1B program is notably used by tech companies and fields requiring skilled labor, supporting small businesses' survival by enabling them to retain vital skilled employees.

entries.title: Trump to cut protections for home health aides, migrant farmworkers
entries.snippet: The U.S. Labor Department, under President Donald Trump's administration, announced plans to eliminate over 60 worker protection regulations. Key changes include rescinding overtime and minimum wage protections for home health care workers and removing union organizing rights for H-2A migrant farmworkers. These efforts align with Trump's aim to deregulate and promote economic growth, as outlined in a previous executive order requiring agencies to cut ten existing rules for each new one. Labor Secretary Lori Chavez-DeRemer, a Republican with bipartisan support, emphasized reducing regulatory burdens. Other proposed rollbacks encompass relaxed safety reporting requirements and the elimination of affirmative action mandates in registered apprenticeships, which critics argue could exacerbate gender and racial inequalities. The administration also plans to reverse Obama-era rules extending labor protections to in-home care workers, arguing they increase service costs, and to undo Biden-era protections for seasonal farmworker unionization, citing stricter immigration enforcement goals. However, no actions have yet been proposed on issues like independent contractors or ethical retirement investing.

entries.title: Incoming Trump Administration Poised to Threaten H-1B Worker Visas
entries.snippet: A second term for Donald Trump promises to bring a new set of challenges for H-1B workers, including a hike on mandated salaries paid by US employers.

entries.title: Why the MAGA Fight Over H-1B Visas Is Crossing Party Lines
entries.snippet: The debate over H-1B visas, which allow foreign workers in specialty occupations to work in the U.S., is causing friction within Trump's MAGA movement and across party lines. Initially, Trump opposed the H-1B program, but his stance softened, later leading to an executive order banning the visas, which was overturned by a federal court. Recently, tech leaders like Elon Musk defended the program, clashing with Trump's allies who see it as harmful. Critics argue the H-1B program depresses wages and promotes outsourcing, while supporters contend it fosters innovation and growth. Bipartisan reform efforts have emerged, calling for higher wages and better protection for U.S. workers, but the tech industry lobbies to maintain the status quo. The future of the program remains uncertain under Trump's administration, with both potential reforms and continued support from key figures in play.

entries.title: Silicon Valley is on edge as Trump's immigration policy sparks fears of a high-tech talent shortage
entries.snippet: Many in Silicon Valley fear the impact of President Donald Trump’s immigration policies on the tech industry's workforce. Concerns have risen about potential restrictions on hiring skilled immigrants, notably through the H-1B visa program which plays a crucial role in staffing the tech sector. During his previous term, Trump increased visa-application denial rates and sought to restrict temporary work visas. Experts and industry leaders worry stricter immigration laws could exacerbate existing high-tech talent shortages, particularly in fields like AI. Despite some hope inspired by figures such as Elon Musk and Vice President-elect JD Vance, who may influence immigration policy favorably, many anticipate challenges ahead. An example highlighted includes a visa holder facing deportation due to job loss amidst uncertainties in the legal immigration landscape.

entries.title: Trump's AI pick sparks vitriol between tech and MAGA supporters - and anti-Indian sentiment
entries.snippet: President-elect Donald Trump's appointment of Sriram Krishnan, an Indian American tech executive, to oversee AI policy has sparked controversy among his anti-immigrant MAGA supporters. Critics, including far-right activist Laura Loomer, argue that Krishnan’s support for removing country-specific caps on green cards contradicts Trump’s "America First" agenda. This appointment has revealed a divide between Trump's tech supporters and far-right followers. Krishnan, a general partner at the venture capital firm Andreessen Horowitz, has a notable background leading product teams at major tech companies. Defenders of Krishnan, including Elon Musk, David Sacks, and Democratic Rep. Ro Khanna, praise his contributions and call for an appreciation of skilled immigrant workers. The debate also touches on H-1B visas, a contentious issue from Trump's first term, with some pushing for stricter eligibility criteria while others favor skilled-based immigration.

entries.title: Elon Musk is on a collision course with Stephen Miller
entries.snippet: Over the holidays, a public feud erupted within the MAGA movement over the H-1B visa program. Elon Musk and other tech executives, who support high-skilled legal immigration, clashed with critics on the right, who argue it suppresses American wages. Musk aggressively defended the H-1B program, attributing his and other talented individuals' contributions to America's strength. The dispute highlighted a split within the GOP, with pro-business factions supporting high-skilled immigration and nativist right factions opposing it. Stephen Miller, a key figure in shaping Trump's restrictive immigration policies, stands as Musk's main adversary. Miller, who will have another significant role in Trump's second term, aims to limit legal immigration. Despite Trump's occasional positive remarks about H-1B visas, Miller's influence suggests restrictive policies will likely prevail. Adding complexity, Trump's appointment of Stephen Miller's wife, Katie, to a position alongside Musk and Vivek Ramaswamy at the Department of Government Efficiency, indicates Miller's continued strong influence in the administration's immigration stance.

entries.title: 'Everybody's got to go home': Ex-Trump adviser Steve Bannon demands end to H-1B visas amid mass tech layoffs
entries.snippet: Former Trump adviser Steve Bannon has strongly condemned the Trump administration’s decision to approve over 135,000 H-1B visas in 2025, labeling it "outrageous." His criticism stems from the context of widespread layoffs among entry-level tech workers in the U.S. and growing fears of job displacement due to advancements in artificial intelligence. Bannon argues that the influx of foreign workers under the H-1B visa program exacerbates challenges for American tech professionals, especially during a period of economic uncertainty and technological disruption. His comments reflect an ongoing debate over the role of foreign labor in the U.S. tech industry and its impact on domestic employment.

parts:
Here’s a detailed update on U.S. H‑1B visa policy, including the latest under the Biden‑era “Modernization Rule” and key actions taken by the Trump administration:

---

## 🇺🇸 **Current H‑1B Policy – Effective January 17, 2025**  
The Department of Homeland Security (DHS) implemented a final “H‑1B Modernization Rule” on January 17, 2025 — during the final days of the Biden administration. Highlights include:  
- Streamlined electronic Form I‑129 filing and updates to specialty-occupation eligibility.  
- Greater flexibility for employers hiring international graduates and high‑skilled workers.  
- Measures to strengthen program integrity and oversight citeturn0search0turn0search6turn0search10.  
- Issuance of revised Form I‑129 to improve processing efficiency citeturn0search0turn0search8.  

These regulatory updates are harder to unwind than executive orders, requiring formal rulemaking to reverse citeturn0search0turn0search16.

---

## 🔥 Trump Administration: Controversial Actions & Policies  

1. **Increased Scrutiny & Higher Denials**  
   - Under Trump’s first term, denial rates surged from ~4% in 2015 to ~15% in FY 2018 citeturn0search1turn0search4.  
   - Tighter “specialty occupation” definitions and restrictions on third-party placements led to more Requests for Evidence (RFEs) and processing delays citeturn0search4turn0search9turn0search11.

2. **Entry Suspensions (2020)**  
   - From April to December 2020, Trump suspended entry of new H‑1B visa holders and extensions, citing impacts from COVID‑19 — later extended into early 2021 citeturn0search29turn0search16.

3. **Executive Orders & Salary Mandates**  
   - April 2017’s “Buy American, Hire American” EO tasked agencies with prioritizing high‑wage, high‑skill applicants and cracking down on “third-party” and consulting-based H‑1B placements citeturn0search13turn0search29.  
   - A 2020 lottery reform prioritized applicants with the **highest wages** citeturn0search29.

4. **Court Overturns & Rule Vacatur**  
   - A federal court struck down the March 2020 executive order that would have temporarily banned new H‑1B grants citeturn0search16.  
   - Some Trump-era salary and occupation rules were vacated by courts and expired in 2021 citeturn0search16.

5. **Second Trump Administration Threats**  
   - Trump’s 2025 inauguration brought new Executive Orders emphasizing merit-based and national‑security considerations, expanding removal and vetting policies across immigration — these orders didn’t directly target H-1B, but signal future risk citeturn0search32turn0search33turn0search30.  
   - Former adviser Steve Bannon criticized the issuance of over 135,000 H-1B visas in 2025, calling it “outrageous” amid tech layoffs citeturn0news27.  
   - Internal GOP infighting surfaced: MAGA hardliners like Steve Bannon and Stephen Miller oppose H‑1B, while tech figures like Elon Musk and VC Vivek Ramaswamy advocate for preserving the program citeturn0news22turn0news26.

---

## 🧭 Summary & Outlook  

| **Policy Element** | **Status** | **Implications** |
|--------------------|------------|------------------|
| H-1B Modernization Rule | In effect (since Jan 17, 2025) | Eases filing, streamlines eligibility, harder to change. |
| Trump-era restrictions | Mostly reversed or court-blocked | Early-term crackdowns largely undone by Biden. |
| New 2025 Trump EOs | Entry vetting, refugee bans, DEI rollbacks | Could reset tone and enforcement priorities. |
| Partisan tension | Deep division within GOP | Outcome unclear in next regulatory cycle. |

- **Bottom line:** Currently, **the H‑1B Modernization Rule remains active**, offering greater efficiency and flexibility while safeguarding integrity. However, the new Trump administration’s executive orders and political pressure from MAGA hardliners mean that H‑1B policy could face renewed scrutiny or tightening. Reversing the modernization rule will require lengthy regulatory procedures, but future executive actions or legislative moves could reshape the landscape.

---

If you’d like, I can track upcoming announcements or forecast the political/legal odds around potential rollbacks.

fallback_items.title: 'Everybody's got to go home': Ex-Trump adviser Steve Bannon demands end to H-1B visas amid mass tech layoffs
fallback_items.snippet: Former Trump adviser Steve Bannon has strongly condemned the Trump administration’s decision to approve over 135,000 H-1B visas in 2025, labeling it "outrageous." His criticism stems from the context of widespread layoffs among entry-level tech workers in the U.S. and growing fears of job displacement due to advancements in artificial intelligence. Bannon argues that the influx of foreign workers under the H-1B visa program exacerbates challenges for American tech professionals, especially during a period of economic uncertainty and technological disruption. His comments reflect an ongoing debate over the role of foreign labor in the U.S. tech industry and its impact on domestic employment.

fallback_items.title: Why the MAGA Fight Over H-1B Visas Is Crossing Party Lines
fallback_items.snippet: The debate over H-1B visas, which allow foreign workers in specialty occupations to work in the U.S., is causing friction within Trump's MAGA movement and across party lines. Initially, Trump opposed the H-1B program, but his stance softened, later leading to an executive order banning the visas, which was overturned by a federal court. Recently, tech leaders like Elon Musk defended the program, clashing with Trump's allies who see it as harmful. Critics argue the H-1B program depresses wages and promotes outsourcing, while supporters contend it fosters innovation and growth. Bipartisan reform efforts have emerged, calling for higher wages and better protection for U.S. workers, but the tech industry lobbies to maintain the status quo. The future of the program remains uncertain under Trump's administration, with both potential reforms and continued support from key figures in play.

fallback_items.title: Elon Musk is on a collision course with Stephen Miller
fallback_items.snippet: Over the holidays, a public feud erupted within the MAGA movement over the H-1B visa program. Elon Musk and other tech executives, who support high-skilled legal immigration, clashed with critics on the right, who argue it suppresses American wages. Musk aggressively defended the H-1B program, attributing his and other talented individuals' contributions to America's strength. The dispute highlighted a split within the GOP, with pro-business factions supporting high-skilled immigration and nativist right factions opposing it. Stephen Miller, a key figure in shaping Trump's restrictive immigration policies, stands as Musk's main adversary. Miller, who will have another significant role in Trump's second term, aims to limit legal immigration. Despite Trump's occasional positive remarks about H-1B visas, Miller's influence suggests restrictive policies will likely prevail. Adding complexity, Trump's appointment of Stephen Miller's wife, Katie, to a position alongside Musk and Vivek Ramaswamy at the Department of Government Efficiency, indicates Miller's continued strong influence in the administration's immigration stance.

entries.title: Musk vows to start a third party. Funding's no issue, but there are others.
entries.snippet: Elon Musk has announced plans to launch a third political party in response to growing dissatisfaction with America's two-party system and a recent controversial tax and immigration bill backed by President Trump. Despite his immense financial resources—having spent $288 million to support Trump-aligned candidates—Musk's political influence is waning. His efforts, including a high-profile but failed bid to influence the Wisconsin Supreme Court race and his controversial U.S. DOGE Service initiative, have undermined his popularity. Though third-party attempts have historically failed in U.S. politics, Musk's entry could still disrupt the system. He has pledged to oppose lawmakers like Rep. Thomas Massie who resist Trump’s spending agenda. Despite overwhelming public support (58%) for a third party, experts doubt Musk's political viability, citing a polarized environment and Musk's polarizing presence. Critics, including Trump allies, ridicule Musk's plans, while scholars suggest the most successful role for him may be as a financial backer rather than a front person. Musk has threatened swift action, stating the “America Party” will be formed if the “insane” spending bill is passed, signaling a volatile and unpredictable path forward for his political ambitions.

entries.title: Musk rails against Trump tax bill, calling it 'a disgusting abomination'
entries.snippet: Elon Musk sharply criticized President Donald Trump’s sweeping tax and immigration bill, calling it “a disgusting abomination” that would saddle the nation with unsustainable debt. Musk, who recently stepped down from his role as head of the U.S. Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE), expressed his strongest opposition yet on X, the social media platform he owns. The controversial legislation includes extensions from Trump’s 2017 tax cuts, eliminates taxes on tips and overtime wages, and commits massive spending to defense and immigration enforcement. The Congressional Budget Office estimates it would add $2.4 trillion to the national debt over the next decade. It also includes significant reductions to social safety nets and dismantles clean energy incentives introduced during the Biden administration—measures directly affecting Musk’s business interests in EVs and solar technology. While some Republican senators welcomed Musk’s critique as a catalyst for revisions, others dismissed it. Senate and House leaders remain divided on how to proceed, with some suggesting the bill be broken up to increase its chances of passing. Despite Musk’s criticisms and potential business repercussions, the White House and GOP leadership continue to support the bill, aiming for its passage by July 4.

entries.title: Elon Musk lauds Trump's foreign policy after reigniting 'Big Beautiful Bill' feud
entries.snippet: Elon Musk recently praised President Donald Trump’s foreign policy achievements, particularly acknowledging Trump’s success in brokering a new 60-day ceasefire between Israel and Hamas. Trump emphasized that Hamas must comply with the deal or face worsening conditions. This development comes ahead of Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s upcoming U.S. visit. Despite Musk's commendation of Trump’s international diplomacy, he has renewed criticism of Trump's flagship legislative initiative, the One Big Beautiful Bill Act, labeling it as "utterly insane" and "political suicide" due to concerns over its fiscal impact and reduced green energy subsidies. Musk has pledged to support Rep. Thomas Massie, a formidable opponent of the bill. In response, Trump criticized Musk’s reception of subsidies and even suggested a review of Musk’s U.S. citizenship status, despite his naturalization in 2002. Additionally, Musk expressed regret over a chainsaw stunt performed with Argentina’s President Milei at a political conference, acknowledging it may have lacked empathy. This sequence of events illustrates a complex and publicly contentious relationship between Musk and Trump.

entries.title: Trump threatens to deport Elon Musk as feud with tech titan reignites: 'We'll have to take a look'
entries.snippet: President Trump reignited his feud with Elon Musk by threatening potential deportation and an investigation by the Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE) into federal subsidies received by Musk’s companies. Despite Musk being a U.S. citizen since 2002, Trump suggested dramatic action in response to Musk's criticism of the One Big Beautiful Bill Act, part of Trump's key domestic policy. Musk condemned the bill as destructive, wasteful, and harmful to future-focused industries, accusing lawmakers of undermining economic progress. He labeled the political landscape a "one-party country" and mocked it as the "PORKY PIG PARTY," also calling for the formation of a new political party. The president responded by highlighting Musk’s past endorsements and his opposition to electric vehicle mandates, which were rolled back in the new bill. The Senate passed the contentious bill by a narrow 51-50 vote. Although Musk endorsed Trump's impeachment and criticized his agenda, he later apologized, and Trump left the door open for reconciliation. Musk also exited his advisory role in DOGE in May due to legal tenure limits for special government employees.

entries.title: Musk Does Backflip on Nasty Trump Feud With Surprise Compliment
entries.snippet: In a surprising turn of events, Elon Musk offered public praise for President Donald Trump, despite a recent heated feud between the two. Musk commended Trump for helping resolve international conflicts, posting on X following Trump’s announcement of a 60-day Gaza ceasefire. This conciliatory remark followed a series of escalating tensions, including Musk condemning Trump’s costly “Big Beautiful Bill,” potentially adding trillions to the national debt, and Trump threatening to revoke federal subsidies Musk’s companies receive. Trump also made a veiled threat about Musk’s citizenship, implying a possible deportation to South Africa and questioning Musk’s reliance on government aid for his companies’ survival. Musk, in response, expressed a strong temptation to escalate the spat but chose restraint. Earlier, Musk had implied Trump’s name appeared in the redacted Epstein files—an accusation he later deleted. The feud also included Musk’s indication of political support for Thomas Massie, a Republican critic of Trump’s bill. The series of confrontations underscore ongoing tensions between the tech mogul and the president, despite Musk’s surprising public compliment.

entries.title: Elon Musk vs. Steve Bannon War Explodes With Prison and Deportation Threats
entries.snippet: A heated conflict has erupted between Elon Musk and Steve Bannon, both former advisors to President Trump. The feud reignited following Musk's public criticism of the president and threats from Trump to investigate and potentially deport Musk. The billionaire predicted Bannon may return to prison, referencing his prior sentence for defying a congressional investigation. In retaliation, Bannon harshly criticized Musk, questioning his patriotism and urging him to return to South Africa. Tensions worsened as Musk labeled Bannon with offensive language and threatened political action against Trump and his allies, including launching a new political party. Meanwhile, Bannon has suggested nationalizing SpaceX and questioned Musk’s loyalty to Trump's voter base. Trump's comments also hinted at possible repercussions for Musk’s businesses through the Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE), escalating the dispute further. Bannon has previously expressed outrage at Musk’s political positions, even threatening physical violence. The feud underscores deepening divides among prominent conservative figures leading up to significant political developments.

entries.title: Trump amenaza con deportar a Musk en medio de una disputa por subsidios y gasto público
entries.snippet: La tensión entre el presidente de EE.UU., Donald Trump, y el empresario Elon Musk ha escalado luego de que Musk criticara una propuesta de ley de gasto impulsada por los republicanos. En respuesta, Trump insinuó en tono aparentemente sarcástico la posibilidad de deportar a Musk, nacido en Sudáfrica pero ciudadano estadounidense, y sugirió que se eliminaran los subsidios gubernamentales a sus empresas, Tesla y SpaceX. Trump afirmó que la eliminación de estas ayudas supondría un gran ahorro para el país y cuestionó los contratos millonarios de Musk, proponiendo una revisión de estos por parte del Departamento de Eficiencia Gubernamental, anteriormente liderado por el propio Musk. En respuesta, el empresario expresó en su red social X su disposición a poner fin a todas las ayudas públicas y amenazó con fundar un nuevo partido político con el que eventualmente competiría contra Trump. Este intercambio marca una notable ruptura en una relación que alguna vez fue de cooperación estratégica.

entries.title: Musk Renews Promise to Start New Rival Political Party-With Patriotic Name-as Trump Debates Deporting Him
entries.snippet:
Elon Musk has renewed his pledge to establish a new political entity, the "America Party," following the Senate's narrow approval of President Donald Trump's controversial "Big, Beautiful Bill." Once a strong Trump supporter and his largest 2024 campaign donor, Musk condemned the bill as excessive and wasteful, calling it "a disgusting abomination." He vowed that if the bill passed, his new party would form, targeting what he calls the "Democrat-Republican uni-party." Musk's tensions with Trump have escalated since leaving his post at the Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE), with Trump responding by suggesting he might consider deporting Musk, a dual U.S.-South African citizen.

Musk has mobilized his vast social media following to oppose the bill and has pledged to support primary challengers against Republicans who backed it. His America PAC spent around $200 million supporting Trump’s campaign, highlighting a sharp reversal in their alliance. Musk’s new party aims to represent the "80% in the middle," though no detailed policies have been unveiled. Andrew Yang, founder of the Forward Party, has expressed interest in collaborating with Musk. Despite challenges faced by previous third-party efforts, Musk's name recognition and resources could provide momentum for his initiative.

entries.title: Donald Trump insinúa la posibilidad de deportar a Elon Musk: "Lo miraré"
entries.snippet: En medio de crecientes tensiones entre Donald Trump y Elon Musk, el presidente de Estados Unidos insinuó públicamente la posibilidad de deportar al fundador de Tesla y SpaceX, en respuesta a sus críticas contra un proyecto de ley de gasto republicano. Aunque formulada en tono aparentemente humorístico, la afirmación ha sido interpretada como una advertencia implícita. Trump también sugirió eliminar subsidios federales que benefician a Musk y dijo que revisaría los contratos gubernamentales con sus empresas. Esta postura contrasta con su apoyo anterior, evidenciado por la compra televisada de un Tesla en marzo. Por su parte, Musk respondió en su red X con mensajes provocadores, aunque manifestó que se abstendría de escalar el conflicto. La deportación carece de base legal debido a la ciudadanía estadounidense naturalizada de Musk, pero el choque revela una creciente ruptura entre los intereses político-empresariales y el posible impacto institucional y económico que esta confrontación puede generar en el país.

entries.title: Trump Suggests He's Open to Deporting Musk as Musk Threatens Some Kind of TBD Nuclear Option
entries.snippet: Donald Trump and Elon Musk are engaged in a renewed public feud, just weeks after resolving a prior dispute. The conflict reignited when Musk criticized Trump’s major spending bill and hinted at forming a new political party, the "America Party," if the legislation passes. Musk also pledged to support Representative Thomas Massie, who opposed the bill, and warned lawmakers against voting for what he described as an excessive debt ceiling increase. In retaliation, Trump attacked Musk on his platform, Truth Social, denouncing the electric vehicle mandate and threatening to revoke Musk’s substantial government subsidies. Trump implied Musk could be forced to cease operations in the U.S. and joked about possibly deporting him to South Africa. Musk responded cautiously, suggesting he might escalate but chose not to immediately. The nature of this “escalation” remains unclear, although previously Musk has made damaging allegations about Trump’s connections. The spat underscores ongoing tensions and exposes personal and political rivalries between two of the most influential figures in U.S. politics and tech.

entries.title: Steve Bannon Vows To Oust Elon Musk From Donald Trump's Inner Circle Before The Inauguration
entries.snippet: Steve Bannon, former advisor to President-elect Donald Trump, has vowed to remove Elon Musk from Trump's inner circle before the inauguration. Bannon is against Musk's support for the H-1B visa program, which allows foreign workers in specialized fields to work in the U.S. The debate highlights infighting within the MAGA movement, with traditionalists like Bannon opposing the program and Musk advocating for its benefits, citing his and other critical workers' contributions to American companies. Bannon's efforts come despite Musk's significant financial support for Trump's campaign. Bannon's history with Trump is tumultuous, having been a key strategist in Trump's first win before leaving the White House and subsequently being convicted of contempt.

entries.title: I cannot describe how strange Elon Musk's CPAC appearance was
entries.snippet: Elon Musk delivered an unconventional and often disjointed speech at the Conservative Political Action Conference (CPAC) in February 2025. Interviewed by Newsmax's Rob Schmitt, Musk occasionally made mathematical errors and statements with logical inconsistencies. Despite these irregularities, the CPAC audience was enthusiastic about his presence. Musk appeared with a MAGA baseball cap and sunglasses, receiving a chainsaw from Argentinian President Javier Milei as a symbolic gesture against bureaucracy. In his speech, Musk emphasized themes such as freedom of speech and reducing government waste, asserting his belief that bureaucratic corruption is rampant. He also criticized the Biden administration's handling of immigration and the Ukraine war, arguing for more pragmatic solutions. Additionally, Musk discussed his aim to improve taxpayer value by eliminating wasteful government spending. Musk's appearance was marked by memorable anecdotes and musings, including remarks on meme culture, freedom of speech, and his personal motivations influenced by American ideals of good and justice.

entries.title: Elon Musk on the Trump administration: 'It's not like I agree with everything the administration does...'
entries.snippet: In a recent CBS interview, Elon Musk offered a balanced critique of the Trump administration, simultaneously supporting certain conservative principles while distancing himself from various controversial policies. Musk criticized the federal spending bill, quipping that it could be "Big or Beautiful, Not Both," highlighting his concerns over financial efficiency. He also addressed his involvement in the Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE), a reform initiative that has faced significant scrutiny, likening it to a scapegoat for broader federal inefficiencies. On trade, Musk remarked that tariffs and trade wars "affect things a little bit," expressing cautious skepticism. He also touched on immigration, advocating for policies that favor foreign talent, humorously encouraging focus on space exploration instead of divisive political issues. Additionally, Musk questioned the scope of governmental control, invoking the inefficiency of entities like the DMV to make his point. Overall, Musk's commentary reflects a nuanced stance that values innovation and efficiency while maintaining critical distance from partisan politics and big government bureaucracy.

entries.title: Is Elon Musk Really Stepping Back From DOGE?
entries.snippet:
On the May 17, 2025 episode of WIRED's Uncanny Valley podcast, hosts delve into Elon Musk's announcement of scaling back his involvement with the so-called Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE) to refocus on his businesses, notably Tesla, which is facing significant challenges. The discussion reviews DOGE's evolution since January, highlighting Musk’s and the Trump administration's controversial involvement. Despite being informally structured and shrouded in ambiguity, DOGE has embedded itself within various federal agencies, employing technologists—often from companies linked to Musk and Peter Thiel—and taking drastic actions like massive layoffs, leasing cuts, and AI integrations.

The hosts express concern over DOGE's use of AI for surveillance and administrative automation, particularly regarding immigrant tracking and worker displacement. They stress the lack of transparency and the alarming speed at which these technologies are being deployed, despite their unproven reliability. Elon Musk may officially reduce his involvement, but the systemic changes initiated under his direction are likely irreversible. The episode underscores DOGE's alignment with industry elite interests and the public's growing awareness of federal government changes, framing it as both a chaotic restructuring and a dramatic shift in public service administration.

content.content: Thought for a couple of seconds

parts:
Here’s the latest on **Elon Musk’s views and statements** regarding H‑1B visas and U.S. immigration policy:

---

## 🧾 H‑1B Visas

### 1. Vowed to “go to war” in defense  
In December 2024, Musk strongly defended the H‑1B program on X, stating:  
> “The reason I’m in America … is because of H1B … I will go to war on this issue the likes of which you cannot possibly comprehend.” citeturn0search7turn0search9  
This positioned him against MAGA hardliners like Steve Bannon, who oppose the program citeturn0news26.

### 2. Acknowledged the system is “broken”  
Shortly afterward, Musk called the H‑1B system “broken” and advocated reforms such as raising the minimum salary and imposing maintenance fees to make hiring foreign labor “materially more expensive to hire from overseas than domestically.” citeturn0search11

---

## 🌍 Immigration in General

### 3. Promotes expanded legal immigration  
Musk has consistently supported increased **legal**, merit-based immigration while opposing **illegal** immigration. For example, he stated:  
> “We should greatly increase legal immigration of anyone who is hard‑working, honest and loves America ... But massive illegal immigration … is insane.” (Nov 2023) citeturn0search33  

He’s also highlighted the absurdity of how easy illegal entry is versus legal paths, calling the system “completely backwards” citeturn0search33.

### 4. Claims on non-citizen voting and SSNs  
In March 2025, Musk participated in a Wisconsin town hall promoting disputed claims about surging Social Security Numbers issued to non-citizens. He framed it as evidence of non-citizen voting increasing. These claims were challenged by experts and fact-checkers citeturn0search34.

---

## 🔥 Political Context & Fallout

- His defense of H‑1B created a rift within the MAGA base—Bannon and others attacked him while Trump publicly sided with Musk, endorsing the program citeturn0search9turn0search7turn0news26.
- Musk’s broader immigration rhetoric ties into his critique of Biden-era policies; Musk amplifies the so-called "importing voters" narrative, a theory mainstream media labels conspiratorial citeturn0search32.
- He also recently launched a political offensive: forming a third party (“America Party”) to counter both Democrats and establishment Republicans, partly spurred by opposition to Trump-backed legislation—though that’s more fiscal than immigration-focused citeturn0news18turn0news23.

---

## 🧭 Summary Table

| Topic | Musk’s Position |
|-------|------------------|
| **H‑1B Visas** | Defends program • Will “go to war” • Calls for system reform (higher wages, fees) |
| **Legal Immigration** | Strongly pro–merit/legal immigration |
| **Illegal Immigration** | Firmly against open/illegal borders |
| **Political Strategy** | Feuding with MAGA over H‑1B • Pushing new party to influence policy |

---

Let me know if you'd like a deeper dive into his X posts, timing of his claims, or how these statements might affect upcoming U.S. immigration debates.

fallback_items.snippet: Steve Bannon, former advisor to President-elect Donald Trump, has vowed to remove Elon Musk from Trump's inner circle before the inauguration. Bannon is against Musk's support for the H-1B visa program, which allows foreign workers in specialized fields to work in the U.S. The debate highlights infighting within the MAGA movement, with traditionalists like Bannon opposing the program and Musk advocating for its benefits, citing his and other critical workers' contributions to American companies. Bannon's efforts come despite Musk's significant financial support for Trump's campaign. Bannon's history with Trump is tumultuous, having been a key strategist in Trump's first win before leaving the White House and subsequently being convicted of contempt.

fallback_items.title: Musk vows to start a third party. Funding's no issue, but there are others.
fallback_items.snippet: Elon Musk has announced plans to launch a third political party in response to growing dissatisfaction with America's two-party system and a recent controversial tax and immigration bill backed by President Trump. Despite his immense financial resources—having spent $288 million to support Trump-aligned candidates—Musk's political influence is waning. His efforts, including a high-profile but failed bid to influence the Wisconsin Supreme Court race and his controversial U.S. DOGE Service initiative, have undermined his popularity. Though third-party attempts have historically failed in U.S. politics, Musk's entry could still disrupt the system. He has pledged to oppose lawmakers like Rep. Thomas Massie who resist Trump’s spending agenda. Despite overwhelming public support (58%) for a third party, experts doubt Musk's political viability, citing a polarized environment and Musk's polarizing presence. Critics, including Trump allies, ridicule Musk's plans, while scholars suggest the most successful role for him may be as a financial backer rather than a front person. Musk has threatened swift action, stating the “America Party” will be formed if the “insane” spending bill is passed, signaling a volatile and unpredictable path forward for his political ambitions.

fallback_items.title: Musk Renews Promise to Start New Rival Political Party-With Patriotic Name-as Trump Debates Deporting Him
fallback_items.snippet:
Elon Musk has renewed his pledge to establish a new political entity, the "America Party," following the Senate's narrow approval of President Donald Trump's controversial "Big, Beautiful Bill." Once a strong Trump supporter and his largest 2024 campaign donor, Musk condemned the bill as excessive and wasteful, calling it "a disgusting abomination." He vowed that if the bill passed, his new party would form, targeting what he calls the "Democrat-Republican uni-party." Musk's tensions with Trump have escalated since leaving his post at the Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE), with Trump responding by suggesting he might consider deporting Musk, a dual U.S.-South African citizen.

Musk has mobilized his vast social media following to oppose the bill and has pledged to support primary challengers against Republicans who backed it. His America PAC spent around $200 million supporting Trump’s campaign, highlighting a sharp reversal in their alliance. Musk’s new party aims to represent the "80% in the middle," though no detailed policies have been unveiled. Andrew Yang, founder of the Forward Party, has expressed interest in collaborating with Musk. Despite challenges faced by previous third-party efforts, Musk's name recognition and resources could provide momentum for his initiative.
